header.title: ‘Racism is rife in LGBT spaces, that’s why we needed Black Pride’
header.postText: LGBTQI communities of colour face ‘widespread racism’ and need a safe space where they can challenge prejudice, say organisers and campaigners who took part in Black Pride today.', 'UK Black Pride is Europe’s largest party for LGBT+ people of African, Asian, Caribbean, Middle Eastern and Latin American descent, and creates a safe space for people from these diverse backgrounds to celebrate their sexuality, culture and shared experiences.', 'It took place in Hackney’s Haggerston Park.', 'Saima Razzaq, an LGBTQI activist who campaigns for inclusive curriculums in school and who spoke at the event, says she has ‘seen racism within LGBTQI spaces all her life’ and took part in the event to help tackle the lack of representation for people of colour.', 'She told Metro.co.uk: ‘People of colour who identify as LGBTQI just don’t have that same opportunity or level of representation.', '‘The reason why Black Pride was created, was because we didn’t feel the issues we cared about were being represented’.', 'She added: ‘Those who question the need for a separate event, need to ask themselves why we felt it was needed in the first place.', '‘No one else is going to do it.’', 'Saima said she was ‘buzzing’ from attending today’s event.', 'Moud Goba, who is one of the co-founders of the event, told Metro.co.uk, that the march was not designed to undermine the work of the Pride event yesterday, but rather to show solidarity with BAME LGBTQI individuals, who can talk frankly and openly about the issues that affect them as a community.', 'She said: ‘We get asked the question a lot, why do we need a separate march, when the London Pride event took place yesterday.', '‘In an ideal world, we wouldn’t need a separate event, in an ideal world we wouldn’t need a Pride event.', '‘But people of colour need a safe space where they are represented.’', 'Moud said the Black Pride event was inclusive and wouldn’t prohibit anyone from attending.', 'She added that there are ‘asylum seekers and refugees who still struggle to get recognised by the Home Office’, those kinds of issues need addressing through events like this.', 'Ms Goba added: ‘At these events, people get to meet people who are like themselves’.

replies.commentText: No doubt a white pride march would be labelled racist, even though it's alright for them to march under whatever banner they choose.
Ian Tucker  your comment reveals the reason
What struggles are we going to represent in the march? Not enough laptop charger points in Starbucks?

We are still by enlarge a majority in terms of ethnicity and culture and sadly a small percentage of people would hijack such a display for their own means. This isn't to say that the same doesn't happen within other types of pride events, however a small percentage of millions of people can create a volumous crowd compared to a handful out of a thousand or so.There are extremists on all sides and those who shout the loudest are often the ones who appeal to a particular media narrative. There are for instance some Ga y> people with absolutely bizzare ideas about how society should submit to their particular beliefs, however they aren't representative about who LBGTQ+ are and sometimes we all have to be careful about who we ally ourselves with because there are some agendas way outside of that.Whilst there are some narcassist who wear their identity as a fashion accessory the majority of G>ay people are often forced to hide who they are out of fear. Now, it is entirely possible that this is a self reinforced or irrational fear, it could be in fact a prejudice born out of ignorance that society is more accepting. If that is the case then a pride march can heal such rifts without it decending into a echo chamber .The ethnic communities do have a bigger internal issue with being LGBTQ+ and this has to be tackled too. It doesn't mean they are anti-white because they are speaking f rom a black pride platform. Though, there is still the danger of such things being hijacked by those with their own view who by happenstan ce are black and LGBTQ+. If they want to be heard properly then they need to ensure that they examine who speaks for them.There is alot that needs to b e said. Black peopl e can b e r a>cist. Gay people can be anti-trans even! Bigotry exists within all camps but people have to give good reasons for the things they believe rather embark upon groupthink.
